title: Casing & Cementing Operations
description: Running casing and cementing in tight-window HPHT wells presents unique challenges. Surge during running, ECD during cementing, and narrow margins for error require careful planning and execution.
objectives: Plan casing runs for surge management
Execute cementing operations within pressure constraints
Respond to well control events during casing/cementing

keyTopics.content: Running casing creates surge pressure. A 7" casing string run at 60 sec/stand may generate 0.3-0.5 ppg surge. In tight windows, this can exceed fracture gradient. Slow running speeds, staged runs, and flotation equipment reduce surge.

Float equipment (auto-fill float collars, differential fill equipment) allows casing to fill gradually, reducing surge. Trade-off: longer running times and more complex procedures. In tight windows, the complexity is worth it.

Cement density must be high enough for zonal isolation but low enough not to fracture the formation. In narrow windows, lightweight cement systems or foamed cement may be required. Understand the trade-off with compressive strength.

Cement displacement creates ECD from friction and density differential. The highest ECD often occurs when heavy cement is in the annulus being displaced by lighter mud. This is frequently the maximum pressure the well sees.
When ECD constraints prevent full displacement in one stage, staged cementing uses intermediate ports. Complexity increases, but allows cementing in otherwise impossible situations.

If a kick is detected while running casing, options are limited. Casing cannot be rotated or reciprocated easily. Pump through casing if possible. If well flows, close annular on casing and proceed with conventional well control.

concerns: Surge during 7" and 5" liner runs in tight HPHT section
No room for error in 1.3 ppg window at TD

operationalPrinciples: Model surge before running - know your limits
Slow is safe - resist pressure to speed up
Plan for cement ECD - it's often the maximum
Staged cementing is better than fracturing
Have a well control plan specific to casing operations
